name: Religion, cinema and censorship
description: Religious narratives and themes have a complicated relationship with censorship, with creators pushing the boundaries for better or worse.

key_work.title: The Blind Man of Siloam lantern slides
key_work.brief_description: The Salvation Army ran Australia’s first production company, The Limelight Department. They produced hundreds of scenes and stories by photographing actors in sets and costumes, printing these scenes on slides and then hand-colouring them before staging performances like The Blind Man of Siloam.

start.title: Samson et Dalila
start.brief_description: Ferdinand Zecca’s 1902 adaptation of the biblical story of Samson and Delilah is an early silent film, shot in black-and-white. Later frames were hand-painted to bring vibrancy and depth.

end.title: The Ten Commandments
end.brief_description: Directed by Cecil B. DeMille and written by Jeanie MacPherson, the film is divided into two parts: a prologue recreating the biblical story of the Exodus and a modern story concerning two brothers and their respective views of the Ten Commandments.

links.description: Cecil B. DeMille also adapted biblical stories for the screen. The Ten Commandments was lauded for its early special effects depicting the parting of the red sea and its use of the Technicolor 2 Process in some scenes.

start.title: Samson and Delilah
start.creator_credit: Cecil B. DeMille and Paramount Pictures
start.brief_description: Cecil B. De Mille’s famous epic style is highlighted in this classic bible story about the legendary strongman Samson and the temptress Delilah, who helped destroy him. Lauded for its lush cinematography, performances, costumes, sets and special effects, it was a box office smash.

constellations_other.description: In Thor: Love and Thunder, Russell Crowe plays one of the most recogniseable gods in the pantheon – Zeus. His scenes lampoon his Oscar-winning role in Gladiator, one of the most recognised films in a classic genre.

end.title: South Park
end.brief_description: When South Park debuted in 1997, it became the first animated pop culture phenomenon since The Simpsons. Known for pushing boundaries and controversial satire, it follows four boys in a sleepy Colorado town but really traverses current events and pop culture.

constellations_other.description: This Constellation exploring animation was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies student Melanie Kavanagh.

links.description: While religious stories helped studios avoid censorship in early Hollywood, religious beliefs have led to censorship on TV. South Park episode 201 controversially featured a depiction of the Prophet Muhammad and was censored by Comedy Central.

links.description: Though rationing during WWII meant less biblical epics were made in Hollywood, DeMille returned with the blockbuster Samson and Delilah in 1949. Biblical epics were popular in early Hollywood as they could bypass the Production Code to include violence and sex.

links.description: The Blind man of Siloam is a magic lantern show created by the Salvation Army in Melbourne. The familiar biblical story was made by printing photos on magic lantern slides and hand-painting them. Similarly, Ferdinand Zecca’s Samson et Dalila featured hand-painted frames.

end.title: Resistance: Fall of Man
end.brief_description: In an alternate 1951, Sgt. Nathan Hale is among a unit of US soldiers sent to aid the British military against invading aliens, known as Chimera. When Hale’s unit is completely wiped out in a surprise attack, he struggles for survival.

links.description: Religious considerations can also affect videogames. The Church of England took offense when the real world Manchester Cathedral appeared in first-person shooter, Resistance: Fall of Man. The church took legal action against Sony for “digital desecration”, who initially pulled the game from shelves.
